facts.text: Two appeals are directed against the judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951, passed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, reversing those of the District Judge at Miraj, dismissing the plaintiffs suit for possession and mesne profits in respect of the suit properties in Civil Suit No. 2 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: Sinha, J. These two appeals are directed against the judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951, passed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, reversing those of the District Judge at Miraj, dismissing the plaintiffs suit for possession and mesne profits in respect of the suit properties in Civil Suit No. 2 of 1940.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1955 is on behalf of the added respondent No. 7, and Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955 is on behalf of the added respondent No. 6 - the State of Bombay which number represents the original first defendant - the Miraj State number merged in the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1955, is on behalf of the added respondent No. 7, and the Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955, is on behalf of the added respondent No. 6 - the State of Bombay which number represents the original first defendant - the Miraj State  number merged in the State of Bombay .

facts.text: The plaintiff-respondent instituted a suit on January 31, 1929, the very last day of limitation, in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj, registered as Original Suit No. 724 of 1930.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of these appeals, it is only necessary to state that the plaintiff-respondent who was the appellant in the High Court, had instituted a suit on January 31, 1929, the very last day of limitation, in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj.

facts.text: The suit was for possession and mesne profits in respect of lands at Malgaon and Takli, on the ground that the then State of Miraj had wrongfully resumed those lands in 1910.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was registered as Original Suit No. 724 of 1930, in that companyrt. The plaintiff prayed in the plaint for possession and mesne profits in respect of lands at Malgaon and Takli, on the ground that the then State of Miraj had wrongfully resumed those lands in 1910,

facts.text: After inquiry, ordered on July 31, 1915, to be recorded as State Sheri-Khata lands, and the usufruct thereof during that period to be appropriated to the Khasgi-Khata of the State.

anchor.surface_text: as part of the State Sheri-Khata, which, after inquiry, was ordered on July 31, 1915, to be recorded as such lands, and the usufruct thereof during that period to be appropriated to the Khasgi-Khata of the State.

facts.text: Plaintiff impleaded the State of Miraj as the first defendant. Defendants 2 and 3 are plaintiffs brothers who relinquished their interest in the suit properties in favour of the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff impleaded the State of Miraj as the first defendant. Defendants 2 and 3 are plaintiffs brothers who are said to have relinquished their interest in the suit properties in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendants 4 to 7 belong to the family of Narso who was, until his death in 1910, recorded in respect of the suit properties, but they did number appear and companytest the plaintiffs claim.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 4 to 7 belong to the family of Narso who was, until his death in 1910, recorded in respect of the suit properties, but they did number appear and companytest the plaintiffs claim.

facts.text: The suit was valued at Rs. 2,065, being 5 times the assessment on the disputed lands for the purposes of companyrt-fee. No valuation was given in the plaint for the purposes of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was valued at Rs. 2,065, being 5 times the assessment on the disputed lands for the purposes of companyrt-fee. No valuation was given in the plaint for the purposes of jurisdiction with reference to the value of the properties claimed.

facts.text: A similar suit had been instituted by the plaintiff in the same companyrt in respect of lands in another village called Tikoni, registered as Original Suit No. 443 of 1928.

anchor.surface_text: A similar suit had been instituted by the plaintiff in the same companyrt in respect of lands in another village called Tikoni. That had been registered as Original Suit No. 443 of 1928, in the Munsiffs companyrt at Miraj,

facts.text: The Tikoni suit was dismissed on November 29, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the two suits proceeded in that companyrt in a very leisurely fashion until November 29, 1939, when the Tikoni suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Plaintiff made an application on June 21, 1940, drawing attention to no value of subject-matter in plaint, value 8 to 10 thousand rupees, Munsiff court had no pecuniary jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: After the dismissal of that suit, the plaintiff made an application on June 21, 1940, drawing the attention of the companyrt to the fact that the value of the subject-matter of the suit had number been mentioned in the plaint,

facts.text: The court allowed the application and directed the plaint to be returned on July 4, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt allowed the application and directed the plaint to be returned to be presented to the proper companyrt, on July 4, 1940.

facts.text: The plaint was re-presented on July 4, 1940 to the court of District Judge at Miraj, numbered as Suit No. 2 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was accordingly re-presented on that very date to the companyrt of District Judge at Miraj, and the same was numbered as Suit No. 2 of 1940.

facts.text: Original first defendant contested the suit including plea of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The original first defendant only companytested the suit on a number of grounds, including the plea of limitation.

facts.text: By petition dated October 27, 1942, defendant stated plaintiff knew value exceeded Munsiff jurisdiction, act not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: By a petition dated October 27, 1942, the defendant brought it to the numberice of the companyrt that the plaintiff despite his knowledge that the value of the subject-matter of the suit was far in excess of the amount of jurisdiction of the Munsiffs companyrt filed the suit in the said companyrt.

facts.text: District Judge dismissed the suit by judgment dated December 12, 1945 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: After recording evidence and hearing the parties, the learned District Judge, by his judgment and decree dated December 12, 1945, dismissed the suit with companyts.

facts.text: On appeal, during pendency, State of Bombay added as 6th respondent, Yuvaraj of Miraj Madhavrao Narayanarao son of Raja Sahib added as 7th respondent as he acquired interest by grant.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defeated plaintiff, during the pendency of the appeal, the State of Bombay was added as the 6th respondent, and the Yuvaraj of Miraj, Madhavrao Narayanarao, son of the Raja Sahib of Miraj, was added as the 7th respondent,

facts.text: Appeal registered as First Appeal No. 104 of 1950 in Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was ultimately registered as First Appeal No. 104 of 1950, in the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Division Bench allowed appeal and decreed suit with costs against first and seventh respondents on November 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of that Court, by its judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951, allowed the appeal and decreed the suit with companyts against the first and the 7th respondents.

facts.text: Before January 1, 1926, law of limitation in Miraj State was 20 years for suit for possession after dispossession.

anchor.surface_text: Before the promulgation, on January 1, 1926, of the Proclamation by State Karabhari, Miraj State, the law of limitation in that State, it is companymon ground, was that the plaintiff had the benefit of the period of 20 years

facts.text: Proclamation on January 1, 1926 made Indian Limitation Act IX of 1908 applicable from February 1, 1926, with modification allowing suits in time under old law but barred under new up to January 31, 1929.

anchor.surface_text: By that Proclamation, the Indian Limitation Act  IX of 1908  was made applicable to that State with effect from February 1, 1926, subject to this modification that all suits which would have been in time according to the old law of the State but would have become barred by limitation

facts.text: Suit filed on January 31, 1929 was within time under the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the suit filed on that date in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj, was admittedly within time, and was subject to the law of limitation under the Indian Limitation Act.

facts.text: Suit barred by limitation as section 14 not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons, it must be held that the suit is barred by limitation. The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

Sub-section  1  of section 14 of the Limitation Act, which admittedly governs the present case, is in these terms -  1 . In companyputing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit, the time during which the plaintiff has been prosecuting with due diligence another civil proceeding, whether in a Court of first instance or in a Court of appeal, against the defendant, shall be excluded, where the proceeding is founded upon the same cause of action and is prosecuted in good faith in a Court which, from defect of jurisdiction, or other cause of a like nature, is unable to entertain it.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exclusion of time during which plaintiff prosecuted another proceeding in wrong court due to defect of jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: In order to bring his case within the section quoted above, the plaintiff has to show affirmatively  1  that he had been prosecuting with due diligence the previous suit in the companyrt of the Munsif at Miraj,  2  that the previous suit was founded upon the same cause of action,  3  that it had been prosecuted in good faith in that companyrt, and  4  that that companyrt was unable to entertain that suit on account of defect of jurisdiction or other cause of a like nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff failed to affirmatively prove all conditions under s14, specifically due diligence and good faith; lower courts misdirected on burden of proof and definition of good faith.

holdings.text: All the conditions necessary to bring the case within section 14 of the Limitation Act have not been satisfied by the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, all the conditions necessary to bring the case within section 14, have not been satisfied by the plaintiff.

holdings.text: Good faith under the Limitation Act is defined by section 2(7) as requiring due care and attention, not the General Clauses Act definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute contains specific definition overriding general one; lower courts erroneously applied negligent-but-honest standard.

holdings.text: The burden of proving the conditions under section 14 of the Limitation Act lies on the plaintiff; it does not shift to the defendant absent plaintiff's proof.
